A **ring of conflict** is a type of [ring](/wiki/Ring "Ring") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The default [randomized appearance](/wiki/Randomized_appearance "Randomized appearance") associated with it is "a ruby ring".[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Descrpition](#Descrpition)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

  - [3.1 Identification](#Identification)
  - [3.2 Farming](#Farming)
  - [3.3 Eating](#Eating)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

[Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") may have a ring of conflict as one of the two random rings in their starting inventory.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Descrpition

Wearing the ring will generate [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict"), causing all monsters within line of sight and a radius of eight squares to attack the nearest monster, including [you](/wiki/You "You"); monsters may resist this effect dependent on level and [monster magic resistance](/wiki/Monster_magic_resistance "Monster magic resistance"). Every even-numbered turn that you wear the ring, your [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition") is decremented by 1.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

As of [commit 2f25556](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/2f255560252b0c18ed468baf94b58654bd5413f7), the chance of resisting conflict now depends on the player's charisma, the monster's level, and the player's level. Conflict is resisted if `rnd(20) > min(19, (ACURR(A_CHA) - mtmp->m_lev + u.ulevel))` - this means there is a minimum 1⁄20 chance of a monster resisting. Conflict also now requires that the monster see the player, not that the monster be in the player's line of sight. These changes are imported from [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack").

## Strategy

- *Main article: [Conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict")*

Rings of conflict are often used for thinning out sizable groups of enemies in areas such as the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") and [Fort Ludios](/wiki/Fort_Ludios "Fort Ludios"), and you can remove it once you are confident in handling the remaining survivors. Try to maintain distance from the other monsters if possible, especially in smaller rooms, and be ready to take the ring off if necessary to avoid an untimely death. Remember that monsters will only use their breath weapons against you - [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection") is advised in some scenarios, both to protect yourself from rays and to aid in taking out other monsters within the group.

Make sure you have access to surplus food, and keep pets well away from the area if you are concerned about them dying—or else possibly killing you themselves. Even simply distracting tougher monsters you do not wish to fight directly, e.g. [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade"), is a valuable use for the ring, regardless of whether they are killed in the ensuing combat: any monster attacking other nearby hostiles is one less monster targeting you.

Rings of conflict are also a popular choice for use on the Astral Plane by players confident in their ability to deal with the hostile [Angels](/wiki/Angel "Angel") that will generate, especially during [speed ascension](/wiki/Speed_ascension "Speed ascension"). In addition, there is a strategy often employed on the Astral Plane in particular, known as "purple rain" - the player [reverse genocides](/wiki/Reverse_genocide "Reverse genocide") [purple worms](/wiki/Purple_worm "Purple worm"), then wears a ring of conflict, and finally [zaps](/wiki/Zap "Zap") or [breaks](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a [wand of teleportation](/wiki/Wand_of_teleportation "Wand of teleportation") to send the worms around the level and clear out many of the powerful monsters present.

### Identification

- *See also: [Identifying rings with a sink](/wiki/Sink#Identifying_rings_with_a_sink "Sink")*

Informal identification is fairly straightforward in theory: If you put on a ring and your tame [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") suddenly begins attacking you, peaceful monsters begin fighting you, or hostile monsters fight each other, it is a ring of conflict. Dropping a ring of conflict into a [sink](/wiki/Sink "Sink") will produce a unique message that reliably identifies it.

The main difficulty in identifying the ring, besides making sure it is non-cursed, is doing so *safely*: Testing a suspected ring of conflict in the presence of a dangerous monster, even if they are peaceful or tame is completely inadvisable. A common [YASD](/wiki/YASD "YASD") is to [curse-test](/wiki/Curse-testing "Curse-testing") a ring as noncursed in a [temple](/wiki/Temple "Temple") and immediately wear it, then quickly dying from the attacks of the [aligned priest](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") standing next to you. Do **not** use the ring near peacefuls armed with wands, such as shopkeepers, unless you have reflection or another means of handling the magical assault.

Finding the ring extremely early in the game can also be similarly dangerous for low-level characters with their starting pets, especially if cursed. A somewhat safe method of testing rings for conflict is to make sure you and your pet are alone in a room, and that your pet cannot deal significant damage; having the pet on a [leash](/wiki/Leash "Leash") also helps, as leashed pets will break free while under conflict.

### Farming

Rings of conflict have uses in [gremlin farming](/wiki/Gremlin_farming "Gremlin farming"), where wearing and removing one while a [gremlin](/wiki/Gremlin "Gremlin") is on a level with [water](/wiki/Water "Water") can be used to multiply their numbers and generate corpses for sacrifice.

### Eating

While the ring of conflict can be [eaten](/wiki/Eating_jewelry "Eating jewelry") for a chance of obtaining conflict as an [intrinsic](/wiki/Intrinsic "Intrinsic"), this has the same nutrition cost as extrinsic conflict, minus the [ring hunger](/wiki/Ring_hunger "Ring hunger") - in addition, conflict is one of the few intrinsics that cannot be stolen by [gremlins](/wiki/Gremlins "Gremlins") or removed by any other means. Combined with the increased frequency of monster attacks, including peacefuls and pets, and some especially dangerous monsters being immune, this is generally a [bad idea](/wiki/Bad_idea "Bad idea").

## History

The ring of conflict first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

## Messages

- You hear loud noises coming from the drain.

  You dropped a ring of conflict down a sink.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), a ring of conflict can be found in [The Spider Caves](/wiki/The_Spider_Caves "The Spider Caves").

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), a ring of conflict can be created at a [furnace](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace") by combining a [ring of hunger](/wiki/Ring_of_hunger "Ring of hunger") and a [ring of aggravate monster](/wiki/Ring_of_aggravate_monster "Ring of aggravate monster").

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/objects.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 572](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/objects.c#L572)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/u\_init.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 165](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/u_init.c#L165)
